did.unittitle: Walter B. Wriston papers, 1918-2006

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note

note.p: The historical or biographical note provides background information about the creator of the material. It does not indicate the contents of the collection. Description of collection contents are found in the Collection and Series level Scope and Contents notes.

bioghist.p: Walter B. Wriston retired as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Citicorp and its principal subsidiary, Citibank, N.A. on September 1, 1984, after having served as Chief Executive Officer for 17 years and in various other positions with the company for 38 years.

Mr. Wriston was born in Middletown, Connecticut, on August 3, 1919 to Dr. Henry Merritt Wriston and Ruth Colton Bigelow. Mr. Wriston had an older sister Barbara Wriston. He graduated from Wesleyan University and the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University. Following a year's service as a U. S. State Department officer and a four-year tour with the U. S. Army during World War II, Mr. Wriston joined Citibank in 1946 as a junior inspector in the Comptroller's Division.

He was assigned to the National Division in 1949 and served in the division's Canadian and Transportation districts for seven years, becoming an Assistant Cashier in 1950, an Assistant Vice President in 1952 and a Vice President in 1954.

Mr. Wriston joined the bank's Overseas Division in 1956, heading the European District for three years, and was named a Senior Vice President in 1958. The following year he was made head of the Overseas Division and was appointed Executive Vice President in 1960. Mr. Wriston became President and Chief Executive Officer of the bank in 1967 and of the corporation when it was formed in 1968. He became Chairman in 1970. During his tenure as Chairman, he instituted a number of banking innovations such as the negotiable certificate of deposit, automatic teller machines (ATMs), and credit cards.

Mr. Wriston was a Director of ICOS Corporation, Cygnus, Inc. and Vion Pharmaceuticals, Inc. He was Chairman of President Regan's Economic Policy Advisory Board, a member and former Chairman of The Business Council, and a former co-Chairman and Policy committee member of the Business Roundtable. He was a Trustee of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, a Life Governor of New York Presbyterian Hospital, and a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

Mr. Wriston was awarded honorary degrees from Brown University, Columbia University, and Hamilton College to name a few. While at Citibank and after his retirement, he lectured at business schools and in other academic institutions. He spoke avidly on economics and the impact of information technology on the banking industry. He testified before US Senate Committees representing Citibank and other banks.

Mr. Wriston was also a writer, whose work "Risk and Other Four Letter Words," is a collection of essays published by Harper & Row, and "The Twilight of Sovereignty" published by Charles Scribner's Sons. Prior to Mr. Wriston's death in 2005, he was working on a third book, "Bits, Bytes, and Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement In a Wireless World." The text will be published posthumously by Hoover Press.

Mr. Wriston married the former Kathryn Ann Dineen in March, 1968. His first wife, the former Barbara Brengle, died in 1966. He had one daughter, Catherine W. Quintal (Mrs. Richard M.), and lived in New York City. Mr. Wriston had two grandchildren Christopher Wriston Quintal and Barbara Catherine Quintal. He was a member of the Links Club, University Club, River Club of New York, Sky Club, Ocean Club of Ocean Ridge, Florida and the Palm Beach Bath and Tennis Club. Mr. Wriston passed away on January 19, 2005 in New York City.
Prior to his death, President George W. Bush honored Mr. Wriston with the Medal of Freedom on June 23, 2004.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content

note.p: The collection scope and content note provides general information about the contents of the collection. More detailed information about the collection can be found in Series Descriptions.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains materials from Walter B. Wriston's office at Citibank on Park Avenue in New York dating from 1918-2006. The materials predominately consist of speeches and resources used to write two of his books "The Twilight of Sovereignty: How the Information Revolution is Transforming Our World" and "Bits, Bytes, and Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement in a Wireless World." The bulk of the material dates to the 1980s and 1990s. The collection includes both paper and electronic media. There are forty-one DVDs and CDs including one CD-ROM. The CD-ROM contains files extracted from Wriston's computers which date from 1989-2006. A number of the file types were so old the files were resaved as plain text files.
The collection consists of five series: Speeches, 1951-2003; Books, 1982-2006, Articles and Interviews, 1963-2004; Audiovisual Media, 1973-2006; and Subject Files, 1918-2005.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Some records may be restricted. See the DCA's General Policy on Access for more information about access to records, especially official University records.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections. Please see the DCA's policy on Copyright and Fair Use for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Walter B. Wriston papers, 1918-2006, Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: This series contains speeches written by Walter B. Wriston. The speeches span from 1951-2003 with the bulk of the speeches from the 1980s. The speeches were produced for an assortment of engagements, such as: Citigroup/Citibank events and meetings, lectures and commencement ceremonies at schools and universities, retirement dinners and introductions, Business Council meetings, testimony before U.S. Federal/State Committees, testimony or remarks at the European and U.S. Chamber of Commerce, Committee and Board of Trustee meetings, Conferences, Club meetings, Association meetings, and the Bank Forum.

The speeches are arranged chronologically. The date the speech was given is listed in the title; however, when there is a date range, the date of the speech is listed in the notes. The folders often contain multiple copies of the speeches including rough drafts, final drafts, and back-up copies. There are also printouts of the computer files from the CD-ROM, "CD_Rom_WBW_Computer Files." These files were extracted from Walter Wriston's computers. In addition, pamphlet versions of some speeches were published by First National City Bank (Citibank/Citigroup) and are included with the correlating speech. Aside from the speeches, there are correspondence and other materials related to the speaking engagements, for example, conference packets, correspondence regarding travel arrangements, thank you letters, slides, and notes.

The final drafts and the back-up copies had spiral bindings which were removed as a conservation measure. If items were bound with rusting paper clips, the paper clips were replaced with non-rusting ones. The paper clips were kept in the collection to maintain the original order and the context of the documents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials are arranged chronologically by book.

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: This series contains drafts and resources Walter B. Wriston used to write his books, "The Twilight of Sovereignty: How the Information Revolution is Transforming Our World" and "Bites, Bytes, & Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement In a Wireless World." Mr. Wriston spoke and wrote avidly on banking, the impact of information technology, and other economic issues. He used his speeches and articles for the basis of his books.

"The Twilight of Sovereignty" In 1987, the working title for "The Twilight of Sovereignty: How the Information Revolution is Transforming Our World" was "The Information Revolution." A draft of the 1987 book proposal is included in the collection. At one point, the volume consisted of twelve chapters but was ultimately shortened to ten. There are drafts of his text in various states from 1987 to 1992. The rough drafts of the manuscripts have some hand written notations and corrections. "The Twilight of Sovereignty" was first published in September 1992 by Charles Scribner's Sons.

Also in this series are correspondence between Mr. Wriston and his publishers from 1990-1993. The bulk of these letters are from Edward "Ned" T. Chase, senior editor at Charles Scribner's Sons. Chase wrote about drafts of the book index and the book jacket. In addition, he sent a number of current newspaper and journal articles to incorporate into the text. Once the book was published, Chase discussed how to promote the text and who to send copies to. There are also copies of Chase's letters requesting reviews as well as some responses to his inquiries. The other individuals from Scribner who Mr. Wriston corresponded with were Hamilton Cain, Assistant Editor; Bill Goldstein, Senior Editor; and Charles Flowers, Assistant Editor. There is also a memo from Richard Vigilante, editor of The City Journal at the time, who assisted in editing the book.
The other correspondence range from 1992-1996. They are letters of thanks to Mr. Wriston for sending autographed copies of his book. In addition, a number of admirers who read the book or saw him during the press junket sent their opinions. Mr. Wriston's sixth grade teacher, Martha Sorensen, also sent a letter commenting on the book.

Included in this series, are printouts of Mr. Wriston's computer files for "The Twilight of Sovereignty." The files were extracted from his computers and saved on a CD-ROM, "CD_Rom_WBW_Computer Files." The printouts of the chapters are arranged chronologically. The date for the materials was derived from the last date it was modified.

In addition, there are reviews for "The Twilight of Sovereignty." They are arranged chronologically and range from 1992-1993. The reviews consist of photocopies, torn out pages, and bound volumes of journals and newspapers

"Bites, Bytes, & Balance Sheets" Prior to Walter B. Wriston's death, he was working on a manuscript. At that time, the manuscript, "The Quick and the Dead: The New Economic Rules of Engagement For A Wired (and Wireless) World," consisted of six chapters. He was in the process of editing and locating a publisher for the book, when due to his illness, the manuscript was put on hold in 2000.

After his death in 2005, his wife Kathryn Wriston hired an editor, John McCarty and Kurt Willett to finish the corrections. The book was extended to ten chapters and re-titled, "Bits, Bytes, And Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement In a New Wireless World." A close friend of Mr. Wriston, the Honorable George P. Shultz, wrote a Forward for the revised manuscript and Mrs. Kathryn Wriston wrote an Afterword. The additional chapters, as well as the other six chapters, were created from the speeches written by Walter Wriston from 1994-2002. Although Mr. Wriston had been ill due to pancreatic cancer, he continued to write speeches and, when possible, spoke at engagements. "Bits, Bytes, and Balance Sheets" will be published posthumously by Hoover Institution Press which intends to annotate the book with updated economic data. There are additional records for Bites, Bytes, & Balance Sheets on the CD-ROM titled "CD_Rom_WBW_Computer Files." The files are drafts of the book from 2000-2006.

"Risk and Other Four-Letter Words" Mr. Wriston wrote another book, "Risk & Other Four-Letter Words" which was published in 1986 by Harper and Row Publishers, now HarperCollins. It is also an edited compilation of his speeches on the then current banking and economic issues. The collection includes two reviews for the book and a bound copy of the text. In addition, the speeches used as the source material for the text are included in series one. They were determined from a study of the text and the speeches in the collection.

arrangement.p: The articles and interviews are divided into articles mentioning Walter Wriston, interviews with Mr. Wriston, and articles by Walter Wriston. They are arranged chronologically within the topics.

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: This series contains interviews and articles written by, about, or mentioning Walter B. Wriston from 1955-2005. There are photocopies and originals of the published articles. Drafts of the articles by Mr. Wriston are included with the published version. In addition, there are correspondence and faxes between Mr. Wriston and the periodical editors and/or producers discussing the particulars of the article or interview. Included in this series are articles which were submitted to periodicals but were not published. The folders are labeled with the name of the article, the author(s), the title of the publication or program, and concludes with the date range of the folder or, if the article is the only item in the folder, the date of the article. Thermal faxes and newspaper clippings were photocopied to ensure the longevity of the article content.

Mr. Wriston wrote articles for: The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, American Politics, the Financial Executive, Forbes, Time, the Harvard Business Review, Vital Speeches of the Day, The Fletcher Forum of World Affairs, Forbes, Executive Speeches, City Journal, The Washington Post, Foreign Affairs, The Cato Journal, American Banker, Reuters World, The Economist, and the Far Eastern Economic Review as well as others. Articles about him were published in: The New York Times, Far Eastern Economic Review, Christian Science Monitor, The Washington Post, Business Week, Finance, Computers in Banking, New York Newsday Forum, The New York Observer, Institutional Shareholders Services, Inc., Chief Executive, Extra Credit, Emerging Market Strategy, The Wall Street Journal, Barron's, Intelligencer, Foreign Affairs, Fortune, Forbes, and The Post-Crescent Newspaper. He was also interviewed on Face the Nation, Meet the Press, Lou Dobbs Moneyline, Lou Dobbs Tonight, Bloomberg Television, and Wall Street Week with Louis Rukeyser to name a few. Wriston did an interview for the Diamond Weekly titled "Walter Wriston: Deregulation in U.S. Overwhelmingly Positive, Too Slow in Japan" which was published in Japanese. The Japanese version and the English version are included in the collection.

did.unittitle: Audiovisual Media, 1973-2006 1973-2006

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The audiovisual media are divided by media, either CD or DVD, and arranged chronologically therein.

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: This series contains audiovisual media, predominately DVDs and CDs, of interviews and speeches by Walter B. Wriston. Also included are DVDs collected by Mr. Wriston on economics and banking as well as "Airport Capabilities: Managing Construction and Public Convenience," a DVD from Bechtel which Mr. Wriston was a board member of. The video and audio files range from 1982-2005. They were separated by media and arranged chronologically.

In addition, there is a CD-ROM of Mr. Wriston's files from his computers in New York City and Connecticut. The files are in IBM and MAC formats and the date of last modification ranges from 1989-2006. Aside from his files on the CD-ROM, there are spreadsheets and word files created by Kurt Willett to assist in the transfer of documents and the creation of a website dedicated to Walter B. Wriston. The spreadsheets list the file name, a description of the file, the date the file was last modified, the size, the original location of the file, and file type. The other files are drafts of speeches, articles, and letters written by Mr. Wriston. The bulk of the files are drafts for two of Wriston's books, "The Twilight of Sovereignty: How the Information Revolution is Transforming Our World" and "Bites, Bytes, & Balance Sheets: The New Economic Rules of Engagement in a Wireless World."

There are DVDs and CDs of Mr. Wriston's interviews and speeches. He conducted a series of interviews for the Idea Channel which are: A Conversation with Walter Wriston and Bob Chitester, A Conversation with Walter Wriston and Herbert Pardes, A Conversation with Walter Wriston and Hugh Carey, A Conversation with Walter Wriston and Robert D. McTeer Jr., A Conversation with Walter Wriston and Charles Brunie, and A Conversation with Walter Wriston and Peter W. Huber. He also appeared on Face the Nation, Meet the Press, Lou Dobbs Tonight, Wall Street Week with Louis Rukeyser, Telecommunications & Information Revolution, and a PBS show called "Electric Money." He wrote the convocation speech for Tufts University's Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy in 2003, but he was unable to attend. His speech was read by Academic Dean Lisa Lynch. The DVD of the convocation ceremony is included in the collection. There is also a DVD created by Citigroup to commemorate Walter Wriston's Presidential Medal of Freedom Award called "Citigroup Honors Walter B. Wriston for receiving The Presidential Medal of Freedom."

note.p: This CD-ROM contains the files extracted from Walter Wriston's computers in New York City and Connecticut. The CD is a FujiFilm CD-R. Also on the CD is written Files in both IBM and Mac formats including Bits, Bytes & Balance Sheets 12-10-06 KLW. KLW are the initials of Kurt Willett who organized Mr. Wriston's files for transfer to the Digital Collections and Archives. The CD-ROM contains five folders Book-Twilight, BB&BS Files, CTMacProfessional, PCProfessional, and WBW Appelworks. There are also files produced for the transfer of Mr. Wriston's files to the Digital Collections and Archives FletcherAudio&VideoTapes (Microsoft Word Document), MacProfessionalDocuments (Microsoft Excel Worksheet), WBWBio (Microsoft Word Document), WBWTimeline (Microsoft Word Document), and WBWWebsite (Microsoft Word Document). In the folder Book-Twilight, there are six additional folders Book3Aug91, Book 3_9_91, Book as of 6_28_90, Book as of 9_16_91, Book on 18 July 91, and Untitled Chapter 2feb 1991. The file types in folder Book-Twilight and its subfolders were too old to open, so they were resaved into plain text documents and the originals were kept the same. In the folder BB&BS Files, there are sixteen Microsoft Word Documents as well as two additional folders McCartyDisk and McCartyNew which also contain Microsoft Word Documents. In the folder CTMacProfessional, there are fifty-four Microsoft Word Documents and one Microsoft Excel Worksheet. In the folder titled PCProfessional, there are twenty-eight Microsoft Word Documents, one Microsoft Excel Worksheet, and one Adobe Acrobat 7.0 Document. In the folder WBW Appleworks, the files were Mac formatted but could not be opened even on a MAC, so the files were resaved into plain text documents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The subject files are organized alphabetically by subject.

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: This series ranges from 1952-2005. It contains: correspondence, awards, Citicorp annual reports, a Citicorp/Citibank brochure, dinner and luncheon correspondence and programs, party preparations and invites, Henry Merritt Wriston articles and memorial tributes, records of the MUFLG (Municipal Union/Financial Leaders Group), and Walter B. Wriston's obituaries and memorial service. The series is arranged alphabetically by subject.

The correspondence are divided into the following groupings: Alan Greenspan Correspondence, American Academy of the Arts & Sciences Membership Correspondence, The Business Council Correspondence, Cato Institute Advisory Board for Trade Policy Studies Correspondence, Citibank/Citigroup Correspondence, Condolence Correspondence, Edward Cardinal Egan Correspondence, Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy Correspondence, General Correspondence, George P. Shultz Correspondence, Henry Merritt Wriston Correspondence, Political Correspondence, Presidential Medal of Freedom Correspondence, Retirement Correspondence, Richard Vigilante Correspondence, Rose and Milton Friedman Correspondence, White House Correspondence, and Writings and Speeches Correspondence. There are also some general emails. Mr. Wriston received presidential holiday cards from Ronald and Nancy Reagan from 1984-1988 which are included in the collection.

Henry Merritt Wriston (1889-1978) was Walter Wriston's father. He was president of Brown University from 1937-1955. The collection contains a photocopy of the Brown Monthly commemorating Henry Merritt Wriston's life. There are other condolences and memorial tributes for Mr. Wriston's father. In addition, there is a list of books Henry Merritt Wriston wrote as well as additional materials.

Mr. Wriston was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom Award in 2004 by President George W. Bush. In honor of his award, Citigroup held a party for him and the guest list is included in this series. Mr. Wriston was also awarded the Appleton High School Hall of Fame Award and attended the reception.

Also included in the collection are the MUFLG (Municipal Union/Financial Leaders Group) records which are minutes from 1977-1985 as well as articles from both the New York Times from 1977-1985 and the Wall Street Journal from 1975-1977. The group was established to assist in the resolution of the New York City fiscal crisis of 1975. It was made of municipal labor leaders and leading bankers which included: Jack Bigel, Alfred Brittain, Willard C. Butcher, Barry Feinstein, Victor Gotbaum, Sonny Hall, Nicholas Mancuso, John F. McGillicuddy, Lewis T. Preston, David Rockefeller, Felix Rohatyn, Lewis Rudin, Sandra Feldman, Walter V. Shipley, and Walter B. Wriston.

scopecontent.p:
This series contains CDs of images and photographic prints of Walter B. Wriston, the Wriston family, Mr. Wriston's colleagues, and his home in Connecticut. The images span from 1925-2004.
The CDs and photographs were sent separately from the main collection in five installments by the Wriston family. The CDs labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 1," "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 2," "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 3," "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 4"were received by the Digital Collections and Archives on July 23, 2007. The CD labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 5" was received on August 2, 2007. The CD labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 6" was received on August 6, 2007. The CD labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 7" was received on August 16, 2007. The final CD labeled "Walter B. Wriston Photographs - CD 8" was received on September 20, 2007.

The prints were created from the image files on the CDs; however, not all of the CD files have accompanying photographic prints. There are seventy-seven image files stored on the eight CDs. There are thirty-nine photographic prints. For each print, the CD name and the file name of the image is listed in the notes field. Some of the images are copyrighted to Harwood Studio, Citicorp/Citigroup, the "New York Times," James Leynse, and Douglas Levere. The copyright information is also listed in the notes field.
